rows.title: Why do we wash hands?

text.eng: Washing your hands with soap is one of the cheapest and most effective things you can do to protect yourself from getting ill. Handwashing with soap stops germs, which cause illness like diarrhoea and COVID, from passing from person to person or to your food and water.

rows.text: Washing your hands with soap is one of the cheapest and most effective things you can do to protect yourself from getting ill. Handwashing with soap stops germs, which cause illness like diarrhoea and COVID, from passing from person to person or to your food and water.

rows.title: Why is soap important?

text.eng: Washing your hands with just water is not enough to remove all the dirt and stool from your hands after you have been to the toilet or changed a nappy. Even if your hands look clean you can still have poop germs on them, especially if you haven't washed your hands with soap. These germs spread when you touch your face, nose, or mouth.

rows.title: What do you need?

text.eng: Washing your hands is easy. All you need is a container of clean water (or a tap), a basin, and some soap. Soap should be kept near a handwashing station. If the station is outside, keep soap near the door so it can be easily accessed, but kept safe.

rows.reference:

Extract:
Sustainble Development Goal - Service Ladder for Hygiene in Households:
- Basic - Availability of a handwashing facility on premises with soap and water.
- Limited - Availability of a handwashing facility on premises lacking soap and/or water.
- No Facility - No handwashing facility on premises.

In some cultures, ash, soil, sand or other materials are used as handwashing agents, but these are less effective than soap and are therefore counted as a limited service.
